title: Quiz 3: Cardiovascular & Blood Drugs
description: Test your understanding of drugs affecting blood formation, coagulation, cardiac function, and blood pressure (Units 8-10).

questions.question: Match the specific antidote to the drug overdose it treats:
questions.explanation: Protamine neutralizes Heparin; Vitamin K reverses Warfarin; Digibind/FAB binds Digoxin; Deferoxamine chelates Iron.
questions.hint: Think about coagulation factors and heavy metals.

questions.question: A patient is prescribed liquid Iron supplements. What is the best method of administration to prevent a common cosmetic side effect?

options.text: Mix with milk to coat the teeth.
Hold in the mouth for 30 seconds before swallowing.
Administer on an empty stomach only.

questions.explanation: Liquid iron can stain teeth. Using a straw bypasses the teeth. Iron should also be diluted with water or fruit juice.
questions.hint: This prevents contact with the enamel.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of Digoxin toxicity? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Digoxin toxicity presents with GI symptoms (nausea/vomiting), Cardiac issues (bradycardia/arrhythmias), and CNS effects (visual halos).
questions.hint: Think about the heart rate and vision.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for administering sublingual Nitroglycerin for an acute angina attack:

items.text: Place first tablet under tongue (wait 5 mins)
If pain persists, take second tablet (wait 5 mins)
If pain persists, take third tablet
Go to emergency room if pain persists after 3rd dose

questions.explanation: Stop activity first. Take 1 tablet every 5 minutes up to 3 doses. If pain persists after the 3rd dose, seek emergency care.
questions.hint: Safety first (sitting), then dosing intervals.

questions.question: A specific electrolyte imbalance known as ___BLANK___ significantly increases the risk of Digoxin toxicity.
questions.explanation: Hypokalemia (low potassium) potentiates the effects of Digoxin, making toxicity more likely even at normal doses.
questions.hint: Low level of K+.

questions.question: Review the Antihypertensive Drug Class table. Which drug belongs to the class that blocks the conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II?

richContent.content:
ClassSuffix/Example
Beta Blockers-olol (e.g., Atenolol)
Ca+ Channel Blockers-dipine (e.g., Nifedipine)
ACE Inhibitors-pril (e.g., Captopril)

questions.explanation: Captopril is an ACE (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme) inhibitor. Propranolol is a beta-blocker; Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker.
questions.hint: Look for the '-pril' suffix.

questions.question: Beta-adrenergic blocking agents (e.g., Propranolol) are safe to use in patients with a history of bronchial asthma.
questions.explanation: False. Non-selective beta-blockers block Beta-2 receptors in the lungs, leading to bronchoconstriction, which can trigger an asthma attack.
questions.hint: Beta-2 receptors affect the lungs.

questions.question: What is the primary mechanism of action for Streptokinase?

options.text: Inhibits Vitamin K synthesis in the liver
Promotes the dissolution (lysis) of insoluble fibrin in thrombi
Blocks the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin

questions.explanation: Streptokinase is a thrombolytic agent that activates plasminogen to plasmin, which breaks down fibrin clots (fibrinolysis).
questions.hint: It is a 'clot buster'.

questions.question: Which nursing considerations are appropriate for a patient prescribed Warfarin (Coumadin)? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Advise the client to use a soft-bristle toothbrush
Encourage a diet high in green leafy vegetables (Vitamin K)
Administer the drug via deep IM injection
Wear an identification band stating anticoagulant therapy

questions.explanation: Warfarin requires PT monitoring and bleeding precautions (soft toothbrush). Vitamin K foods should be consistent/limited as they antagonize Warfarin. Anticoagulants are NOT given IM due to hematoma risk.
questions.hint: Think about bleeding risks and dietary interactions.

questions.question: What is the clinical term for the chest pain caused by insufficient coronary blood flow that is treated with Nitrates?
questions.explanation: Angina pectoris is the clinical syndrome characterized by paroxysmal chest pain due to myocardial ischemia.
questions.hint: First word starts with 'A', second with 'P'.

questions.question: Which antihypertensive agent acts centrally by stimulating inhibitory alpha-adrenergic receptors, often causing sedation and dry mouth?
questions.explanation: Methyldopa (Aldomet) is a centrally acting anti-adrenergic agent. Common side effects include drowsiness/sedation and dry mouth.
questions.hint: Often used in pregnancy-induced hypertension.

questions.question: Match the cardiovascular drug with its specific side effect or nursing consideration:

pairs.right: Persistent dry cough and loss of taste

questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors cause cough/taste loss. Calcium blockers cause edema. Nitrates cause vascular headaches. Hydralazine can cause SLE-like symptoms.
questions.hint: Captopril = Cough; Nitroglycerin = Head pain.

questions.question: Heparin can be administered orally because it is well-absorbed from the GI tract.
questions.explanation: False. Heparin is destroyed by gastric acid and must be given parenterally (IV or SC).
questions.hint: Think about how insulin is given; Heparin is similar in this regard.

questions.question: Which finding would require the nurse to WITHHOLD a scheduled dose of Digoxin?
questions.explanation: Digoxin decreases heart rate. It should be withheld if the pulse is less than 60 bpm to prevent severe bradycardia or heart block.
questions.hint: Bradycardia is a major contraindication.

questions.question: Patients taking ___BLANK___ supplementation may notice their stool turning a black or tarry color, which is a harmless side effect.
questions.explanation: Iron supplements (Ferrous Sulfate) cause stools to turn black/tarry. This must be distinguished from GI bleeding.
questions.hint: A metal used to treat anemia.

questions.question: Which statement regarding Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil) is correct?

options.text: They inhibit the influx of calcium, depressing contractility and dilating coronary arteries.
They are best taken on an empty stomach to avoid interaction.
They are used to treat heart block.

questions.explanation: Calcium channel blockers inhibit calcium influx, which decreases contractility (negative inotropic) and causes vasodilation. They should generally be taken with meals to reduce GI irritation.
questions.hint: Blocking calcium relaxes the muscle.

questions.question: Which of the following instructions are correct for a patient using transdermal Nitroglycerin patches? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Apply to a hairless area of skin
Rotate application sites to prevent irritation
Keep the patch on 24 hours a day without removal
Remove the old patch before applying a new one

questions.explanation: Patches should be rotated and applied to hairless skin. A nitrate-free period (usually removing at night) is often recommended to prevent tolerance.
questions.hint: Think about skin integrity and drug tolerance.

questions.question: Identify the anemia type caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B12 or Folic Acid.
questions.explanation: Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by large, immature red blood cells due to B12 or Folic acid deficiency.
questions.hint: The cells are 'Mega' (large).

questions.question: Why is Vitamin C often prescribed alongside oral Iron supplements?

options.text: To enhance the absorption of iron

questions.explanation: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) creates an acidic environment that enhances the absorption of iron from the GI tract.
questions.hint: Citrus juices help Iron work better.

questions.question: What is a critical nursing consideration for a patient receiving IV Heparin therapy?

options.text: Massage the injection site to increase absorption

questions.explanation: Heparin therapy is monitored via PTT (or aPTT). Warfarin is monitored via PT/INR. Aspirin increases bleeding risk. Massage causes hematomas.
questions.hint: Heparin + PTT (10 letters + 3 letters). Warfarin + PT.
